handNote.p: The scribe is fairly consistent about differentiating between "u" and "v" when intended, rendering the latter with a raised initial minim that at times can almost appear like an ascender. It is tempting to assume that this is just how the scribe renders "u" in the initial position of a word, but examples like "delyver" and "servaunt" in stanza 9 (180v) clarify that this is a deliberate choice and that they do see the two letters as separate glyphs.

For this reason where "u" is in the initial position in a word ("us" in this witness) it has been rendered as "vs." While the scribe consistently makes the initial stroke higher when "v" rather than "u" is meant there is no similar consistent distinction between "u" and "w." An initial "w" can have a raised minim, as can be seen in some places in words like "whan," or "we," but it becomes more difficult to ascertain when the letter is rendered within a word, such as with "bowe." Generally, the upward stroke in the final minim of "w" hooks slightly to the left at the top, then runs into the letter following, while in "u" it tends to complete the final minim then begin the upstroke for the next letter. This can be seen clearly in "plukked" in stanza ten, line six and in "bowe" throughout.

In certain words, such as "our," it is not entirely clear whether the letter intended is "u" or "w" at first glance. Comparing the formation of the final two glyphs in "our" with the formation of the final two glyphs in "merrour" (stanza fifteen, line six), "licour" (stanza twenty-one, line one), and "socour" (stanza twenty-two, line five) suggests that the final two glyphs in "our" throughout are actually "wr." This carries through to words like "towr" (stanza eighteen line three) and "creatowr" (stanza twenty, line four). The latter is especially noticable when compared to "savyour" and "redemptour" in the same stanza (lines two and five, respectively).

Conversely, "out" appears at first to be a similar combination of glyphs to "owr," but taking a closer look at the examples at stanza ten, line five; stanza fourteen, line five; stanza twenty-five, line two show that what appears to be the hook of the "w" glyph is actually formed by the crossbar of the following "t." This same combination also occurs with "but" at stanza ten, line five and stanza sixteen, line eight.

title.title: The Minor Poems of John Lydgate
Edited from all Available MSS., with an Attempt to Establish the Lydgate Canon

zone.line: This folowynge is þe prologe of Johnn Lydgattes
testament which I fownd in Master stantons boke
O howe holsum and glad is the memorie
of crist Ihesu / surmountyng all swetnesse
name of conquest / of triumphe and victorie
thassaunt of sathan / to venquysshe and oppresse
To which name / seynt poule bereth witnesse
of hevene and erthe / and infernall pouste
alle creatures of right / and dewe humblesse
and of hole herte / bowe shall ther kne.
No song so sote / onto the audience
as is Ihesus / nor so full of plesaunce
ageyn alle enemyes / sheld pavis and defence
to hevy hertes / chieff comfort in substaunce

of gostly gladnesse / most comfort in substaunceThe scribe has made an error here and concluded with "substaunce," which is the concluding word of the previous line. The correct word, "suffisaunce," is written following but is partially obscured by what appears to be a blot on the microform. The descenders of the two "f" glyphs can be seen below the blot, however.suffisaunce
chief directorie / to hevene ward the cite
gladdest resort / of spirituall remembraunce
to whome alle creatures / bowe shall ther kne.
To all folkes / that stonde in repentaunce
with herte contrite / made ther confessioun
of will and thought / accomplisshed ther penaunce
and to ther power / done satisfaccioun

line.add: that clayme by mene / of christes passiounThe scribe realized they'd forgotten this line some time after they wrote line six of this verse, and so it is shoehorned between four and six on the page.

the lorde toke on hym / for to bere the charge

The name of Ihesu / swettest of names all
geyn ghostly venymes / holsomest triacle
for whosoevar / vnto this name calle
of cankred surfetes / fynt reles by myracle
to eyen blynd / light lanterne and spectacle
and bryghtest merrour / of all felicite
support and sheld / defence and chefe obstacle
to all that knele / to Ihesu on ther kne.
This royall name / most soverayn of renoun
this name Ihesu / victorious in batayle
of hevenely trivmphes / the laureat guerdoun
The spirituall palme / of gostly apparayle
Celestiall prowesse / whiche may most avayle
to syt with angeles / in ther eternall se
The Imperiall conquest / nat get with plate or mayle
but withe meke knelyng / to Iesu on owr kne.
patriarkes / and prophetes one by one
thre Ierarchies / and all thordres nyne
twelve apostles / and martirs everychone
holy confessours / and every pure virgyne
to blissedd Ihesu / most mekely shall enclyne
ffowles bests / and fysshes of the se
kynde hath taught them / by naturall disciplyne
mekely to Ihesu / to bowe a doun ther kne.
Ther is no love / parfitely I grounded
but it of Ihesu / all parfitenesse is founded
Owr towr owr castill / geyn powrs infernall
Owr portecolys / owr bolewerk and owr wall
Owr sheld owr pavys / geyn all adversite
Owr heritage / owr guerdoun etarnall
to whome all creatures / bowe shall ther kne.
Condygne laude / nor commendacioun
yove to his name / ther can no tonge telle
Of gostly fode / richest refectioun
hede spryng of grace / of lyff conduyt & welle
Jhesu namyd / ther dar no dragoun dwelle
blissedest bawme / of owr felicite
all cancred sores / and poysouns to repelle
from them to Ihesu / that knelle vpon ther kne
This name Ihesu / by interpritacioun
is for to sayne / owr blissed savyour
Owr stronge sampson / that strangled the lyon
Owr lord owr maker / and owr creatowr
And by his passioun / fro deth owr redemptiowr
Owr orpheus / that from captyvite
ffett Erudice / to his celestiall towr
to whome all creatures / bowe shall ther kne.
At welles fyve / licour I shall drawe

to wasshe the rust / of my synnaesThe scribe made an error here, correcting what may have been an a to e. It is unclear what the corrected letter is for sure on the microform, although the word "nowe" where other copies have "newe" may suggest one option and a possible difference in spelling practice between the exemplar and this text. blyve

wher all mysteries / of the old and noweOther witnesses and the standard edition have "newe" here, but the form of the glyph is too similar to "moraly," "toke," and "woundes" in the same stanza to assume this is a malformed "e." lawe
toke origynall / moraly to descryve
I mene the welles / of cristes woundes fyve
Wherby we cleyme / of mercyfull piete
Thurgh helpe of Ihesu / at gracious port taryve

ther to have marcyAgain, this appears to be an "a" where other copies would have "e" or a suspension for "er." "Marci" for "merci" is known, however (see the Middle English Dictionary entry for examples), so there's no need to presume in this case that it's scribal error.
I in Ihesu / sette for Iocunditas
gynnyng and ground / of all gostly gladnesse
E next in ordre / is eternytas

V for vbertas / of spirituall plente

Amonge othar / I that ame falle in age

owr flessh is freill / but short abydynge here

Now in the name / of my lord Ihesus
of right hole herte / in all my best entent
my lyf remembryng / froward and vicious
Aye contrarie / to the commaundement

my youthe myne age / how þat I have spent

duryng my lyff / withe many grete respace
